bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, May 21, 1947

div1.p: Moran wants Kean to explain to Nogueira that there shouldn't be any hostility between Cuba and the U.S. caused by distinguishing between Finlay “discovering” the mosquito theory and Reed “demonstrating” the theory. Kean also mentions his letter to Moran about Guiteras' speech given in Havana in 1900, which gives a proper analogy for the Finlay--Reed discovery.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, May 21, 1947
div1.opener:
To Col. P. S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester Minn.
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
21 May '47
My dear Colonel
div1.p:
You must think that I am like
the gophers which hibernate for the
winter and do not wake up until
hot saummer comes. Well it looks
like that with me. I had a lunch engage
ment with my cousin Prof(Ex). Julian
Coolidge of Harvard, Master of Sowell House
on April 1st. I had a heart attack at
lunch. I got home & tumbled into bed. It wasn't so
very bad, but the doctor was much exer-
cised over it and not only kept me in
bed for several days, but confined me
to the second floor where is my bedroom
& the bathroom. He did not wish me
to come down stairs and be climbing
AC
K
2
the long flight of stairs after breakfast
for the call of nature. As regards
urination I have long had a blue bottle
with a large mouth, which I can use
in my study, and empty in the kitchen
sink next door. Well I felt quite helpless
up there, with all my books and papers
and letters down on the first floor.
So my correspondence was a perfect
mess when last Tuesday the doctor
said that my heart was about as
it was before and if I would be pru-
dent he would discharge me as a
patient. But he appointed Cornelia to
be my Gromyko with a veto power.
So I am not yet a free man. You
see that an old retired lame duck
3
like me has to do just one thing; to earn
his ¾ pay (no allowances, so it is really ½ pay
like the English Army) and that one thing
is to keep alive. So when my friends say
“Well good-by old man take good care
of yourself” I reply “That is my only
job in life - to live, and draw my pay,
and distribute it to my dependents”.
Well I am now cleaning my desk and
answering letters, and I cannot dash
off letters as you can. If I turn my
pen loose no one would ever read it
and I would leave out words and
misspell others, and my friends who
are accustomed to typed letters would
not bother to read them. So I write
slowly and try to make my letters
legible. Now see here are three pages and
AC
K
(4)
all about myself!

I was immensely interested in your fine
letter to Moran and to hear that he
has written, or is writing, his autobiogra-
phy. What you say about it is very
clever and, I doubt not, very true that
it will not conflict with yours. NONE
will conflict with your Magnum Opus
and I am so pleased to have you
speak of it as if you had put pen to
paper on it. C'est la premiere pas qui
coute - “Well begun is half done”.
If I can hold the printed volume of it
in my hand, I will be willing to say
“Now Lord let thy servant depart in peace”.
I had a nice note from Moran, being a
letter of introduction of Dr. Pedro Nagu-
-era, who brought it with him from Cuba.
He had the Pan American where I think
he was staying call me up to make an
5
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
an appointment, but Mrs. Kean who
answered the phone replied that I
was sick and not able to see him.
So he mailed the letter to me, with a
polite letter of regret. I have not writ-
ten to Moran but will try to do so
today. Moran wanted me to explain to
him that I saw no reason for dispute
between Cubans and US. Citizens as to
the respective credit of Finlay and
Reed: that I always spoke of Finlay as
the Discoverer of mosquito transmission
of Yellow Fever and Reed as the Demon-
strator, who with his laboratory training at
Johns Hopkins and his superior facilities
was able to make Finlays' discovery at
AC
K
6
(April 12, 1939. was the date of my letter)
once accepted by the medical profession.

I wrote Moran once my account of the
dinner given by the doctors of Havana
to celebrate the triumphant demonstra-
tion by Reed of Finlay's theory and
the beautiful speech of Dr. Juan Gui-
teras in which he compared Finlay's
work to that of Manson with reference
to the transmission of malaria and
that of Reed to Ross's demonstration
of the malarial agent in the anopheles mos-
quito. This dinner was given on Dec. 22
1900. Dr Finlay and Major Reed seemed
quite satisfied with the point of view
of Dr. Guiteras who made the principal
address and was as I recollect the ‘Master
of the Feast’. What was my amazement
when I read in the biography of Dr Finlay
7
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
written in French by Dr. Francisco Dominiguez
and printed in Paris, a quite full
account of this dinner in which he says
that he Dr. Dominguez got up the dinner
at the request of the Military Governor, Gen.
Leonard Wood! It is amusing that he does
not mention Dr Guiteras's speech or my
being there, altho. I was at that time the acting
Chief Surgeon of Cuba and, as I recollect it,
sat by Dr. Finlay. Also I do not recollect
Dr Dominguez' being there. I think Moran
wanted me to tell this story of my recollect
of the dinner to Dr. Pedro Nogueira and
I would have liked to do so. But Moran
has my letter written April 12, 1939 that
he can show Dr. Noguera if he wants to.
But it reads like a different dinner from
that which Dr Dominguez describes, and
8
he would probably believe the fluent
convincing French of Dr. Dominguez who
was a member of the French Academy of
Medicine. He almost convinced me that I
had a pipe dream. He sent me his
book in 1941 two years after I wrote to Moran
I think you told me that you had the book,
perhaps I gave it to you as I do not
find it here in my den. I hope I did-
Dr. D. is now dead, as are all the men
who I recollect as being at that dinner:
Reed & his two assistants Finlay, Guetiras, Gorgas
Gen. Wood and Dominguez whom I did not
recall. Well this is a long letter and
I must stop and get busy. Mrs Kean is
sick in bed & the Dr. thinks it is nerves &
worry and she must have a rest and stop
worrying. If I had only a few drops
9
of 'that nepenthes which the wife of Thone
in Egypt gave to Jove-born Helena”
but I fear it is not known to modern
medicine. To go back to our question
I fear our American medical writers are
not free from blame. I have a book
on Practice of Medicine by John H. Musser
Professor of Internal Medicine at Tulane
Univ in New Orleans which gives 36 lines to
the History of Yellow Fever and does not men-
tion Finlay, altho he mentions every one
else. His book was printed in 1932 by Lea
& Febiger, Phila. My guess would be that he is
a son of the Phila. Musser of a former generation
